stem: A 40-year-old client was admitted for an Oxycodone overdose and received 0.4 mg of IV Neloxone (Narcan). Based on the documentation in the Opioid Antagonist & Sedation Log, what is the most appropriate nursing intervention for the finding at 2000?

tabs.title: Vital Signs & POSS Log
tabs.content:
TimeConditionRRSpO2POSS Score
1815Found Unconscious682%Unresponsive
1820Narcan 0.4mg IV Given------
1830Post-Narcan 10 min1898%1 (Alert)
1915Post-Narcan 60 min1496%2 (Steady)
2000Post-Narcan 100 min1091%3 (Falls asleep during convo)

options.text: Prepare to administer an additional dose of Naloxone (Narcan)
Discharge the client, as the 0.4 mg dose was effective
Increase the IV fluid rate to flush the Oxycodone from the system
Apply a non-rebreather mask at 15L and monitor for 30 minutes

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing **renarcotization (a1)**. The half-life/duration of action of Naloxone (45–90 min) is significantly shorter than the duration of action of most opioids (3–6 hours). At 2000 (100 minutes post-dose), the Narcan has worn off while the Oxycodone is still active in the blood, causing a return of sedation (POSS 3) and respiratory depression (RR 10, SpO2 91%). An additional dose of Naloxone is required and the client must be monitored for several hours.
clinicalPearls: Naloxone is the 'Speedboat' (fast but small fuel tank); Opioids are the 'Cargo Ship' (slow but massive fuel tank).
Always watch a patient for at least 2 hours after the LAST dose of Narcan to ensure they don't stop breathing again.
Renarcotization is a leading cause of death in successful overdose-reversals who are discharged too early.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the Narcan was 'One and Done' because the patient was alert at 1830.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always compare the durations of action. If the 'antidote' duration is 90 mins but the 'poison' duration is 6 hours, you will ALWAYS need re-dosing or an infusion.

mnemonic.title: Antidote Alert
mnemonic.expansion: Short acting Narcan. Long acting Pain pill. Watch the clock!
